subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: New Zealand dialect
msgSnippet: ... (Heh, heh.)  They re actually equivalent; with the exception of the special cases BATH and CLOTH, the lexical sets correspond to phonemes. They re just
messageBody:
Anthony Grahn scripsit:

> And thank goodness they were not believed: phonemic QS may be
> serviceable but lexical set QS may work even better.

(Heh, heh.) They're actually equivalent; with the exception of the
special cases BATH and CLOTH, the lexical sets correspond to phonemes.
They're just easier to grasp: people find it easier to think about lexical
sets, but really a phoneme is neither more nor less than just what the
members of the set have in common. So it's all good. (Snicker, snicker.)

> And if the participants
> are new to QS, I think their knowledge of linguistics is world class.

Thanks. I would hardly think so; my knowledge is that of a skilled
amateur.

--
As you read this, I don't want you to feel John Cowan
sorry for me, because, I believe everyone cowan@...
will die someday. http://www.ccil.org/~cowan
--From a Nigerian-type scam spam

Anthony Grahn scripsit:

> And thank goodness they were not believed: phonemic QS may be
> serviceable but lexical set QS may work even better.

(Heh, heh.)  They're actually equivalent; with the exception of the
special cases BATH and CLOTH, the lexical sets correspond to phonemes.
They're just easier to grasp: people find it easier to think about lexical
sets, but really a phoneme is neither more nor less than just what the
members of the set have in common.  So it's all good.  (Snicker, snicker.)

> And if the participants
> are new to QS, I think their knowledge of linguistics is world class.

Thanks.  I would hardly think so; my knowledge is that of a skilled
amateur.
